DOC.HEAD: Bush to Attend Drug Summit Despite Peru's Panama Protest
DOC.TEXT: President Bush still plans to attend a February drug summit in Colombia even though Peru, the world's largest cocaine producer, canceled its participation to protest the U.S. assault on Panama. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday that Bush will still go to Cartagena, Colombia as a show of support for President Virgilio Barco, whose nation has been at war with drug lords. Peru issued a strongly worded statement Wednesday condemning the use of force in Panama, recalling its ambassador from Washington and calling for a postponement of the scheduled Feb. 15 summit. It did not offer an alternative date. The other two nations scheduled to attend the summit, Colombia and Bolivia, issued statements condemning the U.S. actions in Panama but did not mention the drug summit.
DOC.NOTE: Juror Says Well-Publicized Drug Buy Viewed as ``Setup''
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors say they will try again to convict the teenager who is accused of selling undercover agents the crack cocaine that President Bush used as a prop in a television address on drugs. A federal judge declared a mistrial Thursday after jurors failed to reach a verdict in the criminal case against Keith Jackson, who is charged with selling the cocaine in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House. Jackson, 18, also is accused of distributing crack at a mall and twice near a high school. Federal drug agents who said they had bought drugs from Jackson were ordered to buy cocaine in Lafayette Park for the president's anti-drug address. Bush displayed a bag of crack cocaine in his national address Sept. 5, saying that it showed the extent of the drug problem. But jury forewoman Cheryl Adams-Huff told The Washington Post in an interview published today, ``The majority of the jurors felt it was a setup.'' U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin scheduled a new trial to begin Jan. 8.

President Bush says he will press Mikhail S. Gorbachev for freedom for Jews denied the right to emigrate from the Soviet Union to join their families elsewhere. ``We'll get the job done,'' Bush promised an audience Thursday at a ceremony in the Old Executive Office Building commemorating the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, which begins Friday. Bush said that during the Dec. 2-3 summit with Gorbachev in Malta, he presented the Soviet president with a list of 20 ``refuseniks.'' Gesturing toward the audience, which was sprinkled with newly emigrated youngsters, Bush said, ``For sake of the children who are with us today, from countries that still deny freedom of faith, we will strive for the religious freedom their parents have never known.'' The Soviet Union has greatly loosened emigration restrictions in recent years, and as a result Bush may grant that country trade concessions denied in previous years.
